column4: fences to shield sacred stumps — so had fences & must have had to protect crops from the sheep
on streets which not always regular
Not in the large temples; Lethaby (1912: 98): The blocks of stone were hollowed out to make them lighter — but no mention of filler.
Waterhouse (1950: 57): The Romans had it and so could have mentioned for the Greeks who he says were less clever engineers.
cornering land marker to increase prices (Glotz 1967: 250)
public registrars kept record of mining concessions and their boundaries
Durant (1939: 270): government leases mines for fee + percentage; see [trait] no. 205
signer rings used to “attest signature for making secure his property”. Could seal it around a string
everyone makes their own – or buys it from the farms
insurance for the borrower whose ship might sink – creditor pays
slave market (Glotz 1929: 131); corn market (Gulick 1902: 19); clothes market, pottery market (Davis 1914: 19)
Durant (1939: 304) – marriage but this about as economic as possible!;  Gulick (1902: 250) – loans
Gulick (1902: 229) – Dyers & tailors with numerous workers
Glotz (1967: 152) – hard stone quarries worked by the state
fixed rate; import tax or a %, whenever landed in port; Glotz (1967: 153) says Athens neither had regular taxes nor a treasury?
metics had to pay license tax
in emergency buys and sells grain
“Greek Friendship”; drinking clubs that become politically significant
Gulick (1902: 277) – membership in the mysteries of Eleusis; Durant (1939: 287) - adoption?
not any more now wife pays, Homeric times the man paid
divided according to citizen and non-citizen – then according to productivity of land
slaves – no taxes, foreigners cannot marry citizens
landholders employ freedmen to supervise slaves
divided into 3 sections of 10 tribes made up of cantons or demes
not administration but more like representation
only for magistrates – because their property belongs to the state in case of maladministration

Durant (1939: 263) — assembly, archons, council; power over – military, finance, foreign relations, magistrates, church, police, justice, enrolment of voters, and next years officials – prepared bills for the assembly to vote on (Glotz 1967: 202)
in the beginning it did but -501 — powers curtailed — though this not stable till 168 BC
Boule-council in charge of other magistrates
council in charge of building, conduct & funds
only case I came across in the military Hipparchs appoint their cavalry officers
each ministry had a secretary who was considered as a magistrate – the most important was the 10th archon; secretary of the Archives – has slaves
every year a censor elected from each of the tribes
full-time [underlined]; magistrates chose 2 members of their family to assist them; Glotz (1929: 221)!
The archons are in charge of the magistrates and preside over the council – bringing up motions etc.
kept by same official who kept archives – included laws, decrees and tragedies
constitution – rules governing choice of leaders
not unless state games, festivals and theater are included – when poor given special funds in order that they might participate
can depose and elect its own president etc.
anyone has right to speak – any citizen
magistrates have special place in a procession, special theater seats and legal rights
offense against any magistrate = offence against state – treason
not particularly as evidence – but oaths taken
whoever misleads the people is a traitor
Sole [underlined]; The people – but more select arbitrators

Gulick (1902: 20): astynomoi – care of the streets, agoranomoi – care of the markets; Glotz (1929: 157): prytaneis – responsible for order in the assembly – aided by 6 archers; Glotz (1929: 188) arrests
each year they must be approved by new council
refusing to give evidence [underlined] - fined 1000 drachmas (Freeman 1946: 26); Glotz (1929: 134) – misleading the people? – if propagator of evil ruling later killed
whoever misleads public or makes a false suit
commercial courts had to judge within a month
Glotz (1929: 236) – for murder if kinsmen of victim unanimously; Durant (1939: 261) – if condemned to death may flee leaving all property
if council, sometimes they reverse judgment to one less harsh
(-); no law against it – choice of the people
all men up to 60 are eligible for military service – after serving 2 years protecting the borders

(-); pensions given to warriors wounded  (Glotz 1929: 131) and their children and wives cared for if killed; dead warriors given public burial (Gulick 1902: 198); individual valor not important (Adcock 1957: 5)
but these her “allies” – in the Athenian confederation
code of laws given by gods especially Demeter Thesmophoros
Durant (1939: 300) - Aphrodite Pandemos goddess of the courtesans
everyone goes to Hades but a few people severely punished there. Later comes idea of Hell. If not buried will never be allowed to cross Styx
Cary & Haarhoff (1961: 308) - not usual but lingered on in parts of Greece till 2nd century AD
oracles and then priests not paid just temple
(+); at the erection of tombs – libations
for different festivals – and some hereditary
The priests never leave the grounds of their sanctuary. But most of the religious official are laymen.

Davis (1914: 213) says not hereditary – anybody could be trained; Waterhouse (1950: 115) – mostly hereditary when not appointed by assembly. All family heads know sacrificial rites, but for mysteries must be initiated and trained
Gods get a special part of booty after war
to judge murder – composed of heads of national cults
Durant (1939: 272) spinning wheel; Stillwell (1951: 231) - just spindle
(-); See Singer et al. (1954: 444) for fullest, yet equivocal statement of the deductions to be made from vase paintings of looms; Gulick (1902: 73) – Homeric societty
the pilot is the real commander
job of individual philosophers – Meton etc.
most individual but Gulick (1902: 82) - tug of war and some sort of ball playing, boat races
lady flute players, dancers and courtesans
